text: the future of agent development isn't
just about writing more code It's about
having the right tools to understand
what your code is doing Langraph Studio
is a powerful agent IDE that sits at the
heart of the Lang Chain ecosystem to
help you build and debug your agents
Today we're going to walk through how to
accelerate your agent development with
Langraph Studio We've streamlined the
setup process making it easy and
straightforward to get started First you
want to make sure you've created your
Langraph application For more
information about Langraphph we'll link
to more videos and documentation below
As you can see for this example we went
with a pretty simple React agent We have
a tably surge tool Then we have our
system prompt defined here as well as
our model And then we use the create
react agent pre-built in order to render
our graph In order to use studio to its
full potential we'll want to check a few
things First we'll want to make sure
that we have a langraph.json file
created and properly configured The
langap.json file is a JSON configuration
file that specifies the dependencies
graphs environment variables and other
settings required to deploy a langraph
application It serves as a central
configuration file for all langraph
applications One of the most important
things when you're making this file is
to ensure that you're pointing to your
graph properly From there we can open up
our terminal and we can make sure that
we have the langraph CLI
installed Great The next thing is to
simply run langraph dev and you'll see
our server spins right
up This command does two things It
launches a local development server that
exposes your graph via an API and open
studio in your browser where you can
immediately start working with your
agent The best part any changes you make
to your code are instantly reflected in
Studio making iterations lightning fast
Now that our local server is up and
running we can go ahead and invoke our
agent and visualize how it runs through
our
graph In Studio we can also easily
manage and test interrupts before and
after each node This is an excellent way
to determine when and where we might
want to add a human in the loop
You can see now it's asking me to
continue before using the search
tool And after a few back and forths it
eventually came back to me with all the
NBA news for today Another amazing
feature of Studio is the ability to fork
conversations We can go ahead and hit
the pencil icon
here and we can say let's see what would
happen maybe if we ask for music news
instead Click fork here and it creates a
new fork of this
conversation Great So now we're seeing
the music news instead You can also do
this at the tool call up Let's go ahead
and modify the search query that I put
in here Let's go back to sports
You can see now we actually did return
back our sports news but our agent was
smart enough to know that we were
searching for music news instead since
we didn't change our human message It
then was able to find the latest music
days and return that back to the user
Next let's jump into our chat tab up
here Our chat tab enables us to
visualize our langraph applications in a
traditional chat UI to see how it would
behave in multi-turn conversations This
is great to bring in business users and
subject matter experts to test your
agents in real time Testing and
iterating on our prompts is easy to do
in Studio since our local server will
auto reload anytime we make changes to
our underlying code You can adjust and
experiment with prompt configurations
structural changes and test your changes
directly within Studio Live enabling for
faster iterations and improve
performance tuning Let's say for example
every time I search for sports news I
wanted to return the latest NBA news We
can make that change here
Additionally let's say maybe I want to
update to a faster or better model Can
do that
here Great You'll see as we've been
doing that our server's been
automatically reloading with these
updates Back in Studio we can test these
changes live Let's try and get the
sports news
again Great You can see now it's
returning the NBA news first This is
expected since I asked it to in the
prompt Additionally if we drill into our
LLM runs we can see that we're using 37
If you'd rather test your prompts out a
few times within Studio before modifying
your underlying code you can dive deeper
into any thread by opening it directly
within playground This gives us
immediate insights and flexibility to
experiment further on the agents
behavior and configurations as you're
reviewing your threads in Linkmith Let's
go ahead and jump into this thread For
example you can click the view LLM run
button then click right here and that'll
open up our thread and playground Now
that we're in our prompt playground
there's a few different things that we
can do We can go ahead and modify our
system prompt So let's maybe ask it to
tell a joke every
time We can also go ahead and change our
model So click here in the prompt
settings We can change our provider
Let's try OpenAI Let's give GPT41 a
chance From here we can rerun
it And you'll see it's adding a joke
after every headline Now let's talk
about one of the most powerful features
of Studio the seamless integration we
have with our production traces in
LanSmith For this we've deployed our
demo react agent with Langraph platform
and we've let our users interact with it
We also set up some rules and some
online evaluators to monitor its
performance Let's go ahead now and
filter down into a trace that we'd like
to debug locally using Studio So for
this application I set up an online
evaluator for relevance So we're able to
filter down to find what were the least
relevant traces that we have in our
production application Let's go ahead
and dive into this trace and get a
better idea as to why it got that score
Opening up this trace you can see it got
a score of 0.1 for relevance As I dive
into it I can see that it got the latest
basketball news but it only returned
news related to college basketball
That's not ideal We have the NBA
playoffs going on right now and I would
assume that any user asking for the
latest basketball news is most likely
referring to the NBA So let's go ahead
and open up our code and let's try and
make some changes in order to debug this
Back in our underlying code let's see
what we can do to make our application
perform a little bit better Looking at
our tavly search tool I can see that our
max search results are at five Let's
upgrade that to 10 maybe Additionally
our search depth is at basic right now
Let's try
advanced Additionally scrolling down
there's a few things that we can do to
modify our prompt You can see we're
passing today's date So maybe we want to
ask the agent to maybe consider the time
of year and what might be most relevant
that time of year for sports Let's go
ahead and modify our prompt a bit Great
We made a bit of a toy example here but
basically we're telling the agent that
if it's the NBA playoffs for example in
May we should return news related to the
NBA first If it's March we should return
NCAA news first since it's March Madness
Obviously this is just a toy example and
there's a lot of different things that
you can do within your application to
make it perform better Now that we've
made all the local changes that we'd
like let's go ahead and see how we can
test our production trace against this
As you can see our server's been
consistently auto reloading as we've
been making changes so we're able to
test this live Let's go ahead and jump
back into Langmith Back in Langmith
you'll see we're still in our production
trace here We can go to this run in
studio button click on this little arrow
All we need to do is make sure that we
have our local endpoint defined We can
either view the original thread or we
can clone the thread locally Let's go
ahead and clone the thread locally Now
that we have our thread clone locally
there's a few different things that we
can do We can go back to the very
beginning modify our input and rerun it
Or we can continue the conversation from
here and see how our agent's going to
perform Let's try and continue the
conversation from here and see that even
though it's just returned college
basketball news if it's smart enough to
figure out what it should return So
let's go ahead and give it a
try You can see now even though it just
responded about college basketball we're
able to continue the thread ask about
basketball news again And actually it
changed the query to the latest NBA
basketball news for today and it went
off and made that tool call You see we
also got 10 results and went a little
bit deeper for each We then got a very
concise well put together response
highlighting mostly the NBA news This is
exactly the result we wanted to And now
we're able to test those changes locally
debug them iterate and then eventually
push those into production once we're
ready Lingraph Studio also comes
standard with production deployments
through Langraph Platform If you'd like
to learn more about Langraph Platform
we'll be sure to link to some more
content below Langraph Studio is
available now and free to use We can't
wait to see how it transforms your agent
development workflow Give it a try and
let us know what you build with it Check
out our docs below and join our
community to share your experiences and
get support Thanks for watching and
happy building
